zemenak peter zamis village attorneys ____________ virginia l szymski village clerk preface this volume is a republication of the 1996 the village of westmont illinois the original arrangement and the original numbering system have been retained ordinances no 99170 adopted  have been included in this republication the following paragraphs are reprinted from the preface of the 1996 this a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the village of westmont illinois source materials used in the preparation of the the 1972 as supplemented  and ordinances subsequently adopted by the board of trustees the source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof the absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this the reader can locate any section of the 1972 as supplemented and any subsequent ordinance included herein the chapters of the been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage notes which tie related sections of the which refer to relevant state law have been included a table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the included at the back of this system the chapter and section numbering system used in this the same system used in many state and local government codes each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash the figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter thus the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 12 and the first section of chapter 6 is 61 under this system each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments for example if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 61 and 6 2 is desired to be added such new section would be numbered 615 new articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or in the case of articles may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject and in the case of divisions may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject the next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division new chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters page numbering system the page numbering system used in this a prefix system the letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume the number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion in the case of a chapter of the the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter in the case of an appendix to the the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix the following are typical parts of codes of ordinances which may or may not appear in this this time and their corresponding prefixes co de cd  co de app en dix cd a1 co de co mp ar ati ve tab les cct 1 sta te la w ref ere nc e tab le slt 1 co de ind ex cdi 1 index the index has been prepared with the greatest of care each particular item has been placed under several headings some of which are couched in lay phraseology others in legal terminology and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees there are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested looseleaf supplements a special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication with this system the publication will be kept uptodate subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the affected page or pages will be reprinted these new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages keeping this publication uptodate at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication as revised pages are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions it is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and in addition that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes acknowledgments this publication was under the direct supervision of milton e lefkoff supervising editor and charles vignos editor of the municipal tallahassee florida credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publishers staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project the publisher is most grateful to mrs virginia szymski village clerk steve penczak deputy village clerk and mr john zemenak village attorney for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication it is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a ordinances which will make the active law of the village readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the daytoday administration of the villages affairs copyright all editorial enhancements of this copyrighted by municipal the village of westmont illinois editorial enhancements include but are not limited to organization  table of contents  section catchlines  prechapter section analyses  editors notes  cross references  state law references  numbering system  code comparative table  state law reference table  and index such material may not be used or reproduced for commercial purposes without the express written consent of municipal the village of westmont illinois copyrighted material municipal the village of westmont illinois 2000 adopting ordinance ordinance no 9629 an ordinance adopting and enacting a new code of ordinances for the village of westmont illinois be it ordained by the mayor and board of trustees of the village of westmont dupage county illinois as follows the ordinances village of westmont illinois which is published by municipal consists of chapters 1 inclusive is hereby adopted as the codification of the general ordinances of the village of westmont and shall be known as the westmont village  all ordinances of a general or permanent nature which were enacted on or before  and not included in the recognized and continued in force by reference therein are hereby repealed the repeal provided for in hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary the repealer provisions of of this ordinance shall not be deemed to repeal modify amend or otherwise affect the validity enforceability meaning or interpretation of any of the following a any ordinance or resolution adopted on or after   b any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money authorizing the issuance of any bonds or other evidence of indebtedness of the village or authorizing any contract or other obligation assumed by the village  c any ordinance or resolution in connection with any annual appropriation or tax levy  d any ordinance conferring any right or franchise  e any special or temporary ordinance or resolution  f any ordinance or resolution relating to the salaries of village officers or employees  g any ordinance annexing territory to the village  h any ordinance naming renaming opening accepting or vacating streets or alleys  i any ordinance relating to zoning or rezoning  j any ordinance of a general or permanent nature ordered by the village board to be printed in the form of a separate book or pamphlet unless another penalty is expressly provided every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the village be punished by a fine of not less than $1000 nor more than $75000 each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense the penalty provided by this section unless another penalty is expressly provided shall apply to the amendment of any whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance in addition to the penalty prescribed herein the village may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits additions or amendments to the village when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the village board to make the same a part of the village shall be deemed to be incorporated in the so that the reference to the the additions and amendments ordinances adopted after  that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the village shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the village  this ordinance shall be in full force and effect after its passage approval and publication in pamphlet form as provided by law passed and approved by the mayor and board of trustees of the village of westmont dupage county illinois this 20th day of may 1996 ayes ordinance appearing in the ordinances and the terms of the original ordinance on file with the village clerk the terms of the original ordinance shall control notwithstanding anything herein to the provision of the any ordinance rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than $1000 nor more than $75000 each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense a penalty imposed for any violation of this include or consist of a requirement that the defendant perform some reasonable public service work such a but not limited to the picking up of litter in public parks or along public highways or the maintenance of public facilities the penalty provided by this section unless another penalty is expressly provided shall apply to the amendment of any whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance in addition to the penalty prescribed above the village  continuing violations whenever in this in any ordinance of the village any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or a violation of this or whenever in such doing of any act is administrative code hearing systemestablished a there is hereby established and created within the village an administrative code hearing system to enforce and adjudicate violations violations of the following chapters of the municipal the village of westmont the  as the same may be amended from time to time 1 advertising 2 animals 3 illicit discharge detection and elimination 4 buildings and building regulations 5 businesses 6 engineering and flood control 7 nuisances 8 fire prevention fire protection and emergency services 9 health and sanitation 10 housing 11 solid waste 12 streets sidewalks and other public places 13 trees and landscapes 14 utilities 15 vegetation 16 appendix a zoning the village board may from time to time designate such other village ordinances and which are subject to this administrative code hearing system b the provisions of 65 ilcs 51221 and 65 ilcs 511311 et seq of the illinois municipal hereby adopted and incorporated into this chapter as if fully set forth herein c the provisions of this chapter shall apply to administrative adjudication proceedings to the extent that they are not inconsistent with the provisions of the set forth specific procedures for the administrative adjudication of particular code provisions d as used in this chapter words or terms shall have the following meanings unless the context or usage clearly indicates that another meaning is intended building code means any village ordinance law housing or building code or zoning ordinance that establishes construction plumbing heating electrical fire prevention sanitation or other health and safety standards that are applicable to structures in the village or any village ordinance that requires after notice the cutting of weeds the removal of garbage and debris the removal of inoperable vehicles or the abatement of nuisances from private property building inspector means a state county or municipal employee whose duties include the inspection or examination of structures or property in a municipality to determine if zoning or other code violations exist property owner means the legal or beneficial owner of a structure  212018   5102018 hearing procedures nonexclusive the provisions of this chapter shall not preclude the village from using other methods or proceedings to enforce and adjudicate the other ordinances of the village including without limitation the institution of an action in the dupage county circuit court or the united states district court or any administrative proceeding  212018 administrative composition the administrative code hearing system shall provide for one or more hearing officers all with the power authority and limitations as set forth in this chapter  212018 hearing officer a appointment the village manager shall appoint one or more qualified hearing officers to perform the functions set forth in this section b independent contractor a hearing officer shall be employed as an independent contractor of the village and shall not be considered an employee of the village a hearing officer may be removed with or without cause by the village manager c qualifications to qualify as a hearing officer an individual must 1 be an attorney licensed to practice law in the state of illinois for at least three years  2 be in good standing with the illinois supreme court attorney registration and disciplinary commission  3 complete a formal training program approved by the village manager and the village attorney consisting of a instruction on the rules of procedure for administrative code hearings  b orientation to each subject area of the will be adjudicated  c observation of hearings conducted by illinois municipalities that have adopted the administrative system  and d participation in hypothetical hearings including ruling on evidence and issuance of final orders d compensation authorization for compensation for a hearing officer shall be made by the mayor and village board of trustees villages annual budget process compensation shall be determined by the village manager within approved budget limitations e authority and powers hearing officers shall have all powers necessary to conduct fair and impartial hearings including but limited to the power to 1 hold conferences for the settlement or simplification of the issues  2 administer oaths and affirmations  3 hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the allegation of a violation  4 issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant testimony at the hearing upon the request of the parties or their representatives  5 preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing including all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing  6 issue a determination based on the evidence presented at the hearing on whether a violation occurred or exists the hearing officers determination shall be in writing and shall include a written finding of fact decision and order including the fine penalty or other action with which the defendantproperty owner must comply  and 7 impose penalties consistent with applicable assess costs upon finding a defendant liable for the charged violation except as expressly provided in this chapter  212018   5102018 violation notice a a notice of any violation violation notice shall be issued in writing by the persons authorized under this chapter shall contain information as to 1 description of the real estate sufficient enough for identification  2 the nature of the violation  3 a correction order allowing for a reasonable time to make the repairs and improvements required to bring the property dwelling unit or structure into compliance with the provisions of this   4 a statement informing the property owner or violator information regarding right to appeal  5 a statement of the right for the village to file a lien in accordance with state and municipal law  6 shall be certified  and 7 shall constitute prima facie evidence of the violation cited b all code officers building inspectors and other officers as well as other specifically authorized individuals of any department of the village shall have the authority to issue violation notices c any individual authorized to issue violation notices who detects a violation is authorized to issue a violation notice thereof and shall serve the violation notice in the manner set forth in the d the correctness of facts contained in any violation notice shall be certified by the person issuing the notice his or her name to the violation notice at the time of issuance e the records of the community development departmentcode enforcement division shall retain the original or a facsimile of the violation notice and keep it as a record in the ordinary course of business f the violation notice or a copy thereof shall be admissible in any subsequent administrative or judicial proceeding to the extent permitted by law  212018   5102018 service a service of any violation notice shall be made as follows 1 personal delivery by leaving a copy of or by handing the notice to the property owner occupant or lessee of the property or business if present  or 2 mailing the notice by certified mail to the property owner occupant or lessee of the property or business  or 3 if mailed notice is returned showing that the letter was not delivered a copy thereof shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or about the structure or property affected by such notice b if service of notice is provided by first class mail for any violation notice or for any hearing notice said service shall be deemed sent and shall be complete on the date the notice is deposited postage prepaid in the united states mail the counting of any time period as set forth in the begin to run on the date the notice is deposited postage prepaid in the united states mail  212018   5102018 hearings all hearings conducted under the administrative code hearing system shall be conducted by a hearing officer and shall be in accordance with the following rules and procedures 1 a record of the hearing shall be made by tape recording or other appropriate means 2 the parties may be represented by counsel present witnesses and crossexamine opposing witnesses 3 no continuance shall be authorized by the hearing officer in proceedings under this chapter except when absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the defendant lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance any continuance authorized by a hearing officer under this section shall not exceed 25 days 4 all testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation 5 parties may request the hearing officer to issue and the hearing officer shall have the authority to issue subpoenas to direct the attendance and testimony of relevant witnesses and produce relevant documents 6 the formal and technical rules of evidence shall not apply evidence including hearsay may be admitted only if it is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs 7 in a hearing on the propriety of impoundment of a vehicle any sworn or affirmed report that i is prepared in the performance of a law enforcement officers duties and ii sufficiently describes the circumstances leading to the impoundment shall be admissible evidence of the vehicle owners liability unless rebutted by clear and convincing evidence 8 each hearing shall culminate in a determination of liable or notliable by the hearing officer or a determination of liability based upon the failure of the defendant to appear at the hearing 9 the hearing officer shall upon a determination of liability assess fines and penalties in accordance with the order the property owner to correct the violation in addition the hearing officer shall have the discretion to assess costs upon finding a defendant liable for the charged violation in no event shall the hearing officer have authority to a impose a penalty of incarceration  or b impose a fine in excess of $75000 for a single violationper day the violation exists 10 the maximum monetary fine imposed under the be exclusive of costs of enforcement or costs incurred by the village to secure compliance with the villages ordinances and shall not be applicable to cases to enforce the collection of any tax imposed and collected by the village 11 if the defendant or his or her attorney or designee fails to appear on the date set for the hearing the hearing officer may find the defendant in default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to the existence of a code violation 12 rights of occupants in the case of a building code violation only no action for eviction abatement of a nuisance forcible entry and detainer or other similar proceeding shall be threatened or instituted against an occupant of a dwelling solely because such occupant agrees to testify or testifies at a building code violation hearing 13 defenses to building code violations in the case of a building code violation only it shall be a defense if the property owner his or her attorney or any other agent or representative proves to the hearing officers satisfaction that a the building code violation alleged does not in fact exist or at the time of the hearing the violation has been remedied or removed  b the building code violation has been caused by the current property occupants and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the property owner to maintain the dwelling free of such violations the current occupants continue to cause the building code violations  or c an occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry by the property owner or his or her agent to all or a part of the dwelling for the purpose of correcting the building code violation  212018   5102018 judicial review any final decision by a hearing officer that a violation does or does not exist shall constitute a final determination for to two minutes in length on the recorded master tape res no 9876  1 2 7201998 electronic attendance at meetings rules a rules statement it is the decision of the village of westmont that any member of the corporate authorities may attend via electronic means such as by telephone video or internet connection any regular or special open meeting of the corporate authorities convened pursuant to properly published notice at which a quorum is present including workshop meetings of the corporate authorities but not including committee meetings provided that such attendance is in compliance with these rules and any applicable laws electronic attendance at closed meetings by a member of the corporate authorities is not permitted b prerequisites a member of the corporate authorities may attend a meeting electronically if the member meets the following conditions 1 the member shall notify the village manager at least 48 hours in advance of the scheduled meeting so that necessary communications equipment can be arranged inability to make the necessary technical arrangements will result in denial of a request for remote attendance the request for electronic attendance shall be made using the attached request written form which should be submitted to the village manager at least 48 hours in advance of the scheduled meeting in the event advanced transmission of the written request form is impossible the request to attend a meeting remotely and electronically shall be otherwise communicated to the village manager at least 48 hours prior to the start of the meeting thereafter within 48 hours following the meeting such written request form shall be submitted to the village manager 2 the member must assert one of the following three reasons why he or she is unable to physically attend the meeting a the member cannot attend because of personal illness or disability  or b the member cannot attend because of employment purposes or the business of the village of westmont  or c the member cannot attend because of a family or other emergency c authorization to participate 1 the village manager after receiving the electronic attendance request shall inform the corporate authorities of the request for electronic attendance 2 after establishing that there is a quorum is physically present at a meeting where a member of the corporate authorities desires to attend electronically the presiding officer shall state that i a notice was received by a member of the corporate authorities in accordance with these rules and ii the member will be deemed authorized to attend the meeting electronically unless a motion objecting to the members electronic attendance is made seconded and approved by 23 of the members of the corporate authorities who are physically present at the meeting if no such motion is made and seconded or if any such motion fails to achieve the required vote by the members of the corporate authorities physically present at the meeting then the request by the member to attend the meeting electronically shall be deemed approved and the presiding officer shall declare the requesting member present after such declaration by the presiding officer the question of a members electronic attendance may not be reconsidered 3 only one member of the corporate authorities may attend a meeting electronically at any one time in the event more than one member requests remote attendance at a specific meeting selection shall be made by the village manager based upon the first request received by the village manager 4 a trustee attending a meeting electronically shall be entitled to receive his or her regular compensation for that meeting d adequate equipment required the member participating electronically and other members of the corporate authorities must be able to communicate effectively and members of the audience must be able to hear all communications at the meeting site before allowing electronic attendance at any meeting the village by proper authorization shall provide equipment adequate to accomplish this objective at the meeting site e minutes any member attending electronically shall be considered an offsite attendee and counted as present electronically for that meeting if the member is allowed to attend the meeting minutes shall also reflect and state specifically whether each member is physically present or present by electronic means f rights of remote member 1 a member permitted to attend electronically will be able to express his or her comments during the meeting and participate in the same capacity as those members physically present subject to all general meeting guidelines and procedures previously adopted and adhered to 2 the member attending electronically shall be heard considered and counted as to any vote taken accordingly the name of any member attending electronically shall be called during any vote taken and his or her vote counted and recorded by the clerk and placed in the minutes for the corresponding meeting 3 a member attending electronically may leave a meeting and return as in the case of any member provided the member attending electronically shall announce his or her leaving and returning 4 a member of the corporate authorities is eligible to use this procedure and may attend electronically no more than three times per fiscal year g committees boards and commissions these rules shall not apply to any committees boards and commissions established by authority of the village of westmont exh a 7202009 consent agenda the village manager shall direct the preparation of the consent agenda which shall include such matters as the village manager shall determine are routine all items listed on the consent agenda will be enacted by one motion agenda any item removed from the consent agenda shall be placed at the end of new business and shall be discussed and considered after all other items on the posted agenda are considered  6182012 procedures for public participation at public meetings a members of the public may address public officials at meetings of the village board its committees commissions and other subsidiary bodies in accordance with g of the illinois open meetings act 5 ilcs 120206g b public comments are limited to three minutes per speaker c the subject of public comments shall be reasonably related to matters identified on the meeting agenda andor other village business d any person desiring to speak shall register their request with the public body prior to the meeting if practical e any person desiring to speak on behalf of a group and not solely as an individual must register as a group speaker and any person speaking on behalf of a group is limited to six minutes f public comment shall be taken at one particular time within the meeting eg at open forum at a village board meeting and shall not be allowed at other times unless the chair of the meeting recognizes the participant speaker or unless required pursuant to the public hearing process established by state law g to ensure accurate record keeping public members are encouraged to provide their full name and their home address prior to speaking however provision of an address is not required to speak h a registered speaker cannot give their allotted minutes to another person i statements are to be directed to the village boardcommitteecommission or subsidiary body as a whole and not to an individual member j public comment is not intended to require boardcommitteecommission members to provide answers to the speaker k discussions between speakers and members of the audience are not allowed l repetitive public comments should be avoided to the extent practical of prior public comment eg agreeing with a prior speaker m the chair of the meeting may create and enforce reasonable additional rules to preserve order and decorum eg prohibiting applause cheering booing shouting use of profanity or the use of signs banners and placards n the chair may suspend the rules in order to provide more public comment as heshe deems appropriate o the following conduct is prohibited during public participation 1 acting or appearing in a lewd or disgraceful manner  2 using disparaging obscene or insulting language  3 personal attacks impugning character andor integrity  4 intimidation  5 disorderly conduct as defined by state law  p any speaker who engages the public body in a prohibited manner as identified above shall be called to order by the chair  q any person who violates these rules or who otherwise disrupts the order and decorum of the meeting may be removed exh a 682017 editors note exh a adopted  adopted provisions pertaining to procedures for public participation at public meetings but did not specify the public health safety and welfare curfew means a prohibition against any persons walking running loitering standing or motoring upon any alley street highway public property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the village except officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty with reference to a civil emergency b whenever a civil emergency exists the village president shall declare the existence by means of a written declaration setting forth the facts which constitute the emergency c after proclamation of a civil emergency the village president may order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the village or to the village as a whole as he deems advisable and applicable during such hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the interest of public safety and welfare d after the proclamation of a civil emergency the village president may also in the interest of public safety and welfare make any or all of the following orders 1 order the closing of all retail liquor stores including taverns and private clubs or portions thereof wherein the consumption of intoxicating liquor and beer is permitted 2 order the discontinuance of the sale of alcoholic liquor by any wholesaler or retailer 3 order the discontinuance of selling distributing or giving away gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle 4 order the discontinuance of selling distributing dispensing or giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever 5 issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property e the proclamation authorized by this section shall be effective for a period of up to seven days unless terminated by a proclamation of the village president indicating that the civil emergency no longer exists or unless it is continued or renewed for an additional time period with the consent of the village board f upon issuing the proclamation authorized in this section the chief of police shall notify the news media within the general area of the village and shall cause three copies of the proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency to be posted at the following places within the village 1 the village hall 2 the police station 3 the post office g any person violating the provisions of this section or executive order issued pursuant thereto shall be guilty of an offense and shall be punished as provided in section 18    161997 1052009 secs 25232535  reserved article vii  code of ethics footnotes  16  state law reference pecuniary interest in contracts 65 ilcs 5486 declaration of policy the proper operation of democratic government requires that public officials and employees be independent impartial and responsible to the people they serve  that government decisions and policies be made in the proper channels of the governmental structure  that public office not be used for personal gain or to advance the interest of a family or relatives  and that the public have confidence in the integrity of its government in recognition of these goals there is established this code of ethics for all village public officials whether elected or appointed paid or unpaid and for all village employees 2300 9201999 purposes the purpose of this code of ethics is to establish ethical standards of conduct for all village public officials and employees by setting forth those acts or actions which are incompatible with the best interest of the village and its inhabitants this code of ethics is founded upon the principle that no individual should receive any financial or other gain beyond that legally defined by reason of serving as a public official or employee of the village and that no private party or taxpayer including public officials or employees or their family members should receive any benefit from village action beyond that which is available to any other private party or taxpayer due to their relation to or as a result of privileged information or support provided by any public officials or employees 2301 9201999 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning business entity means any business proprietorship firm partnership person in a representative or fiduciary capacity association venture trust or corporation charity means any organization as defined by the internal revenue usc 501c3 which is exempt from taxation confidential or privileged information means public records and information exempt from inspection and copying under any provision of the illinois freedom of information act  that are designated and labeled as confidential by the board of trustees or any committee thereof and any matter or information properly the subject of a closed meeting or session pursuant to the illinois open meetings act  ethics board means the board consisting of the village president village clerk and one village trustee as appointed by the village president the village president may change the appointment of the village trustee from time to time in his or her discretion the village president shall also appoint a separate village trustee as an alternate ethics board member who shall serve only in the event that a conflict of interest prevents an ethics board member from hearing a matter the ethics board shall conduct hearings of purported violations of this ethics article and the state officials and employees ethics act and shall impose disciplinary action andor fines for violations as it deems appropriate ethics officer the village manager or designee shall serve as the village ethics officer and shall receive and investigate all complaints of violations of this ethics article by public officials and employees and may recommend disciplinary measures to the ethics board family member means a spouse  children and grandchildren and their spouses  parents and spouses parents  and brothers and sisters and their spouses gift means any gratuity discount entertainment hospitality loan forbearance or other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including but not limited to cash food and drink and honoria for speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of a public official or employee interest means any material direct or indirect benefit accruing to a public official or employee or their family members whether in the public officials or employees own name or the name of any person firm corporation association or trust from which the official or employee is entitled to receive any financial benefit as a result of a contract or transaction that is or that is known will become the subject of an official act or action by or with the village  provided however that the term interest shall not include 1 any such benefit accruing as a result of any such contracts or transactions that by their terms and substance confer on all other citizens of the village the opportunity and right to realize similar benefits 2 any such benefit accruing to a public official or employee solely by reason of ownership of less than onehalf of one percent of the publicly traded stock of a business entity realizing such a benefit 3 the employment of any family member of a public official in any temporary position or in any permanent parttime position provided that such family member is otherwise qualified and meets all requirements for such employment and is not treated in any manner differently than any other employee in a comparable position for purposes of wages or benefits paid or work evaluations performed official act or action means any legislative administrative appointive or discretionary act of any public official or employee of the village or any agency board committee or commission thereof public official or employee means any person officer or employee holding a position by election appointment or employment in the service of the village whether paid or unpaid including members of any agency board committee or commission thereof  provided however that independent contractors shall not be considered public officials or employees transaction means any matter including but not limited to contracts work or business with the village the sale or purchase of real estate by the village or any request for zoning amendments variations planned development approval or special use permits involving or requiring any official act or action of the village 2302 9201999   5172004   452010 cross reference definitions generally  12 footnotes  17  state law reference 5 ilcs 1401 et seq  18  state law reference 5 ilcs 120101 et seq  5 ilcs 1401 et seq ethical standards a conflict of interest no public official or employee shall perform or participate in an official act or action with regard to a transaction in which he has or knows he will thereafter acquire an interest  provided however that any interest permitted or prohibited under applicable state laws and regulations as they may be amended from time to time shall be permitted or prohibited under the same circumstances and conditions as therein set forth b reserved c reserved d preacquisition of interest no public official or employee shall acquire an interest in or position himself to be beneficially affected by any transaction or the subject matter thereof at a time when the public official or employee believes or has reason to believe that such transaction will directly or indirectly be affected by an official act or action of such official or employee e unauthorized disclosure and use of confidential or privileged information no public official or employee shall disclose without proper legal authorization confidential or privileged information concerning the property government or affairs of the village nor shall any public official or employee use any such confidential or privileged information to advance the interest of such public official or employee or his family members nothing contained in this section shall prevent the village manager in his discretion from disclosing to any village staff such confidential or privileged information as he may determine to be necessary to carry out his duties as chief administrative officer of the village and to enable such staff members to carry out their respective duties and responsibilities f misrepresentation of village positions no public official or employee shall state that the village has made a particular decision or adopted a position when such public official or employee knows that the village has in fact not duly made or adopted such decision or position this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit any public official or employee from stating his personal views concerning any matter so long as such views are clearly identified as personal views and not as the official decision or position of the village g appearance except as otherwise provided by law no public official or employee shall appear on behalf of any private person or business entity other than himself or a family member 1 before any village agency board committee or commission  or 2 before any other agency board committee commission or court regarding the subject matter of any transaction that is pending before the village or in which an interest of the village is directly involved provided however that nothing in this subsection g shall be construed to prohibit an appearance without compensation by a public official on behalf of his constituents in the course of such public officials duties as a representative of such constituents or in the discharge of such public officials public or civil obligations or to prohibit an appearance by a public official or employee as a duly authorized representative of the village h public property no public official or employee shall use or permit the use of villageowned vehicles equipment materials or property for profit or for personal convenience except with an administrative order of the village i special treatment no public official or employee shall grant any special consideration treatment or advantage to any person or business entity beyond that which is available to every other citizen 2303 9201999   5172004 political activities and business transactions a appointments or employment no appointment to or employment in any village position shall be dependent on any political activity or business transaction b condition of employment no employee shall be required to engage in any political activity or business transaction as a condition of employment 2304 9201999 disclosure of interest any public official or employee who has an interest in a contract or transaction that is or that is known will become the subject of an official act or action in which such public official or employee is involved shall disclose on the record of the agency board committee or commission which performs such official act or to the village manager in the case of employees the nature and extent of such interest and shall not participate in any manner in the official action of the village agency board committee or commission 2305 9201999 violations a jurisdictional authority all complaints regarding a potential violation of any provision of this code of ethics shall be made in writing to the ethics officer upon the receipt of any complaint the ethics officer shall immediately forward the complaint to the ethics board and may recommend disciplinary action to the ethics board the ethics board shall thereafter schedule a special meeting convened to consider the alleged violation of this code of ethics pursuant to the procedures described in this section the ethics board shall provide at least seven days advance written notice to the alleged violator of the date and location of the special meeting the ethics board shall convene this special meeting within 45 days after receiving a written complaint forwarded to it by the ethics officer an emergency meeting of the ethics board may be called by the village president or by any three trustees b procedures for disciplinary action the ethics board and the alleged violator shall each have the opportunity to present a caseinchief in which they may present evidence call witnesses cross examine witnesses and make opening and closing arguments the state rules of evidence applicable to civil proceedings shall govern the village president shall preside over the hearings a written decision with a finding of facts and the imposition of disciplinary action if any shall be made by the ethics board within seven business days after the hearing and shall be transmitted to the alleged violator via certified mail c disciplinary action a finding by the ethics board that any public official or employee has violated any provision of this code of ethics shall to the extent allowed by state law constitute cause for reprimand censure suspension removal or other appropriate disciplinary action d fines any person prosecuted for and found guilty by the ethics board of violating any provision of this code of ethics may be fined not more than $500000 for each such offense in cases of a continuing violation the village attorney is authorized to apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for a restraining order or injunction to abate such violation if the ethics board finds after a full hearing that a complaint is frivolous it may impose a fine against the person initiating the complaint up to $500000 e appeals any public official or employee found guilty by the ethics board of violating this code of ethics may appeal such decision to any court or tribunal of competent jurisdiction or make any such other appeals as provided by state law and due process requirements any such appeal shall not stay any disciplinary action ordered by the ethics board unless so directed by a court or tribunal of competent jurisdiction f reconsideration of transaction any transaction that was the subject of an official act or action of the village in which any public official or employee has an interest prohibited by this code of ethics or which involved the violation of a provision of the code of ethics shall be officially reconsidered upon discovery disclosure or determination of such interest or violation 2306 9201999 distribution the village clerk shall cause a copy of this code of ethics to be distributed to every public official and employee of the village within 30 days after enactment of this code of ethics each public official and employee elected appointed or engaged thereafter shall be furnished a copy of this code of ethics before entering upon protection act by reference the illinois false claims act illinois whistleblower reward and protection act 740 ilcs 1751 et seq as amended from time to time is hereby adopted by reference to be applied within the corporate limits of the village to the extent permitted by law  9192011 whistleblower reporting policy a purpose the village has adopted by reference the illinois whistleblower act and the false claims act which are comprehensive statutes designed to expose the fraudulent actions of employees politicians and contractors in connection with government obligations resources and employment by encouraging the reporting of such fraudulent behavior the reporting of concerns of illegal or dishonest or fraudulent activity promotes open government protects the health safety and welfare and improves the community however it is understood that baseless allegations are subject to discipline up to and including termination b policy a whistleblower is an employee of the village who reports an activity that heshe considers to be illegal or dishonest or designed to deceive others resulting in the village suffering a loss andor the perpetrator achieving a gain the whistleblower acts in good faith and has reasonable grounds for believing the information disclosed provides evidence of an improper transaction or a violation of the law or the policies and ordinances of the village examples of illegal or dishonest activities are violations of federal state or local laws billing for services not performed or for goods not delivered and other fraudulent activity c procedure if an employee has knowledge of or a concern of illegal or dishonest fraudulent activity the employee may contact one of the following to discuss the situation and evidence  hisher immediate supervisor  human resources administrator  village manager  illinois state police at 271 7854377  attorney general at 312 8143000  inspector general from attorney generals office at 888 8144646 alternatively a written complaint may be submitted to any of the above the reporting employee must exercise sound judgment to avoid baseless allegations making allegations maliciously recklessly or with the foreknowledge that the allegations were false is a serious offense and may result in discipline andor penalties as provided in illinois law or in the policies of the village once a complaint is made the human resources administrator will gather information or conduct an investigation unless the complaint is regarding the human resources administrator the human resources administrator may enlist the assistance of police department personnel for investigative purposes in the event that the human resources administrator is the target then the chief of police or chiefs designee may investigate the complaint either the chiefchiefs designee or the human resources administrator may request assistance from an accountant or auditor if deemed appropriate the complaint and information gathered pursuant to the complaint will be kept confidential except as needed to complete the investigation resolve the complaint comply with applicable law or otherwise properly inform and receive feedback from the board of trustees or legal counsel the investigation shall begin as soon as practicable after a complaint is lodged and shall conclude as expeditiously as possible the village manager will make a report to the board of trustees within 14 days of the complaint or at the next available village board meeting once the investigation is completed the findings along with a recommendation made in consultation between legal counsel and the village manager will be reduced to writing and submitted to the board of trustees the finding may be placed in a personnel file and disseminated if it is determined to be appropriate to do so the finding may lead to disciplinary action on the part of the village as defined the villages personnel complaint procedure shall not be construed to create any independent right to any specific remedy or to a hearing  9192011 secs 25472560  reserved article viii  state officials and employees ethics act footnotes  19  editors note competitive bidding it is the policy of the village to engage in competitive bidding and to award contracts to the lowest responsible bidder for public improvement projects where the costs of said projects exceed the minimum amount established by state statute 65 ilcs 5891 the act as amended from time to time it is further the policy of the village to comply with the requirements of the act other applicable provisions of illinois law and any policies approved by the village when awarding contracts for public improvement projects except as limited by section 2568  1262018 exceptions to competitive bidding the village is not obligated to comply with the competitive bidding requirements of state statute under the following circumstances 1 where the public improvement project involves renovations or improvements to existing village buildings which cost in excess of the minimum amount established by state statute and competitive bidding is impractical for such work 2 where competitive bidding is impractical because the public improvement project is capable of only being primarily performed by a single source or 3 where an emergency exists rendering competitive bidding impractical when one of said exceptions to the competitive bidding requirements applies the contract for the public improvement project shall only be awarded if approved by a vote of twothirds of the village trustees then holding office as required by state statute additionally if the public improvement project involves renovations or improvements to existing village buildings the village shall first make reasonable attempts to obtain three proposals for the work and the contract shall be awarded based on the lowest responsible proposal competitive bidding is not required for the purchase of materials for the use of professional or unique services or for contracts between the village and the federal government or any agency thereof  1262018 advertising footnotes  1  cross reference reference liquor control act 235 ilcs 511 et seq article i  in general definitions all terms used in this chapter and not otherwise defined including definitions set forth in section 10 111 shall be construed according to the definitions given in 235 ilcs 51301 1331 the following terms shall be construed according to the definitions provided in this section alcoholic liquor means any spirits wine beer ale or other liquid containing more than onehalf of one percent of alcohol by volume which is fit for beverage purposes club means a corporation organized under the laws of the state not for pecuniary profit solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale and consumption of alcoholic liquors kept used and maintained by its members payment of annual dues and owning or hiring or leasing a building or space in a building of such extent and character as may be suitable and adequate for the reasonable and comfortable use and accommodation of its members and their guests and provided with suitable and adequate kitchen and dining room space and equipment and maintaining a sufficient number of servants and employees for cooking preparing and serving of food and meals for its members and guests  provided that such club files with the local liquor commissioner at the time of its application for a license under this chapter two copies of a list of names and residences of its members and similarly files within ten days of the election of any additional member such members name and address  and provided that its affairs and management are conducted by a board of directors executive committee or similar body chosen by the members at their annual meeting and that no member or any officer agent or employee of the club is paid or directly receives in the form of salary or other compensation any profits from the distribution or sale of alcoholic liquor to the club or its members or its guests introduced by members beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed and voted at any annual meeting by the members or by its board of directors or other governing body out of the general revenue of the club hotel means a building or group of buildings and facilities used in conjunction with one another kept used maintained advertised and held out to the public to be a place where food is actually served and consumed and sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to travelers and guests whether transient permanent or residential in which 25 or more rooms are used for the sleeping accommodations of such guests and having one or more public dining rooms where meals are served to such guests such sleeping accommodations and dining rooms being conducted in the same building or buildings in connection therewith and such building or buildings being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity such building or group of buildings and facilities may also include up to two indoor cocktail lounges room service facilities banquet facilities or conference center rooms providing dancing or live entertainment and recreational facilities such as a golf course a hotel liquor license shall permit more than one restaurant within the hotel only if the restaurants are being predominantly serviced by a common kitchen facility licensed premises means the building in which the business of a licensee is conducted together with any approved outdoor seating area for businesses licensed for sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises only and shall not include any other outdoor area or portion of the lot on which such building is located except as follows 1 a golf course shall be considered part of any premises licensed to sell alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises  2 any class 11 or class 12 license for a special event may include specific permission to sell alcoholic liquor in an outdoor area subject to such conditions as the local liquor commissioner may impose and such area will then be considered to be part of the licensed premises  3 a liquor licensed establishment whose license allows for consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises and which is located in the central business district within the designated area for the westmont street fair may permit consumption of alcoholic beverages when purchased on the premises outdoors in designated areas for the westmont street fair and only during the westmont street fair pursuant to the westmont street fair alcohol policy developed by the local liquor commissioner restaurant means any public place kept used maintained advertised or held out to the public as a place where the primary business is the service of meals where meals are actually and regularly served without sleeping accommodations where adequate provision is made for sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity and a sufficient number of employees to prepare cook and serve a reasonable variety of meals for its customers and where the preponderance of meals served are prepared on the premises a restaurant shall be so designed that excluding banquet rooms food preparation areas restrooms and other areas not designed for seating of patrons at least 75 percent of the total floor area shall be designated solely for the service of meals with service of alcohol as an amenity and no more than 25 percent of the total floor area shall be designated solely for the service of alcoholic liquor and hors doeuvres or for entertainment the mere availability and service at any premises of cold sandwiches hors doeuvres or other similar foods will not standing alone be deemed sufficient to constitute such premises a restaurant within the meaning of this definition it being the intent of this definition that the primary business conducted on premises to be licensed as restaurants under this chapter shall be the service of meals no premises which charges any kind of entrance fee or requires a minimum amount to be spent solely for the purchase of alcoholic liquor or other beverages shall be deemed to be a restaurant under this definition sale retail sale means any transfer exchange or barter in any manner or by any means whatsoever for a consideration and not for resale including all sales made by any person except a person acting in the privacy of his home or as part of a delivery of liquor without additional charge with a meal or with entertainment or the providing of samples of liquor as a part of a promotion or sales device of any kind 3 the dispensing of liquor 4 reasons such license has been refused in addition to the criteria for the applicant and the premises as set forth in section 1033 the following additional factors may be considered by the local liquor with the provisions of this chapter and the relevant provisions of the zoning ordinance appendix a and the building codes chapter 18 of the village  3 the advisability of granting such license in view of the public good and convenience of the village  4 the length of time an applicant has been operating as an entity or business in the village or elsewhere  5 the experience or history of the applicant with the village including the prevalence or lack of contacts with the police department fire department code enforcement department or any other enforcement body of the federal state or county governments  6 the relevance of a liquor license for successful operation of the business  7 the applicants previous experience with the handling of liquor including prior violations of liquor control laws or the absence thereof  8 the experience of the applicants liquor manager including prior violations of liquor control laws or the absence thereof  9 the neighborhood in which such licensed establishment is to be operated and the potential impact on such neighborhood if a liquor license is granted  10 the geographical distribution of licenses in the village  11 input from village staff members and the police department as to the likely impact of the establishment on the community  12 any other factors which may be relevant to the issuance of such license d in granting this chapter the local liquor commissioner shall also establish the nature of any permissions being given in conjunction with the granting of the license including without limitation permission for license a personal privilege  not subject to attachment transfer devolution a license issued under this chapter shall be purely a personal privilege good for not to exceed one year after issuance unless sooner revoked as provided in this chapter and shall not constitute property nor shall it be subject to attachment garnishment or execution nor shall it be alienable or transferable voluntarily or involuntarily or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated such license shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution but it shall cease upon the death of the licensee  provided that the licensee and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor may continue the business of the sale or manufacture of alcoholic liquor under the order of the appropriate court and may exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of such decedent or after such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license but not longer than six months after the death bankruptcy or insolvency no refund shall be made for any portion of the license fees paid for any period entertainment fashion show presentation or performance which involves or includes dancing including but not limited to servers hosts hostesses dancers models or other performance artists or role playing interactions all performance dancers shall be fully clothed which shall mean the wearing of nontransparent pants skirts dresses and shirts or tops which substantially cover the body without limitation performance dancing in bathing suits underwear or pasties are prohibited this shall not limit hawaiian dancers belly dancers and other heritagelike dancers so long as the dancing is not performance dancing of any kind shall be submitted to the local liquor commissioner or designee a minimum of 30 days prior to the date of the performance there is no fee for the request the determination as to whether such performance dancing will be allowed will be made by the local liquor commissioner upon a casebycase basis no performance dancing may occur without the express written consent of the local liquor commissioner 3 nonperformance dancing by patrons to music may be allowed in certain licensed premises subject to the express written approval of the local liquor commissioner as provided in section 1035c and further subject to an inspection of the licensed premises by the village fire department prior to issuance of the liquor license to determine the compliance of the premises with applicable statutes ordinances rules or regulations regarding occupancy of the licensed premises during such dancing by patrons f casinovegas nights it shall be unlawful for any licensee its manager or other person in charge of premises licensed to sell alcoholic liquor to conduct any casino night or vegas night on the licensed premises without first having having informed the village police department of the date and time of the event and having arranged for police security therefor village police officers who are hired for such security shall be paid chemicals are present on the licensed premises at any time h limitations on the sale and promotion of alcoholic liquor 1 it shall be unlawful for any licensee or any employee or agent of any licensee on licensed premises where alcoholic liquor is sold or offered for sale for consumption thereon to engage in any of the following practices a delivery of two or more drinks to any one person at one time except sale or delivery of wine by the bottle or carafe  b sale offer for sale or delivery to any person of an unlimited number of drinks during any set period of time for a fixed price except at private functions not open to the public  c sale offer for sale or delivery of drinks to any person or group of persons on any one day at prices less than those charged the general public on that entire day except at private functions not open to the public  d increasing the volume of alcoholic liquor contained in a drink without a proportionate increase in the price charged for such drink as offering room service to registered guests in hotels licensed for such service  e selling pitchers or the equivalent including but not limited to buckets carafes or bottles of alcoholic liquor which are customarily sold in such manner and which are delivered to two or more persons at one time i visibility of interior of premises no premises upon which the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises is licensed other than as a restaurant hotel or club shall be permitted to have any screen blind curtain partition article or thing in the windows or upon the doors of such licensed premises nor inside such premises which shall prevent a clear view into the interior of such premises from the street road or sidewalk at all times and no booth screen partition or other obstruction nor any arrangement of lights or lighting shall be permitted in or about the interior of such premises which shall prevent a clear view of the entire interior from the street road or sidewalk all rooms where liquor is sold for consumption on the premises shall be continuously lighted during business hours by natural light or artificial white light so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall be clearly visible in case the view into any such licensed premises required by the foregoing provisions shall be wilfully obscured by the licensee or by him wilfully permitted to be obscured or in any manner obstructed then such licensee shall be subject to the revocation or suspension of his license in order to enforce the provisions of this section the local liquor commissioner shall have the right to require the filing with him of plans drawings or photographs showing the clearance of the view as required in this subsection j outdoor sales it shall be unlawful for any by the local liquor commissioner or the state commission which is not inconsistent with law b upon any suspension or revocation of the state liquor license issued to any licensee the local liquor license held by such licensee shall be automatically suspended or revoked accordingly c in lieu of or in addition to suspension or revocation of a liquor license the local liquor commissioner may levy a fine on the licensee for such violation the fine imposed shall not exceed $100000 for each violation and each day on which the violation continues shall constitute a separate violation not more than $1000000 in fines under this section may be imposed during the period of the license d no liquor license shall be so revoked or suspended and no licensee shall be fined except after a public hearing by the local liquor commissioner with at least three days prior written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend himself if the licensee fails to appear and defend himself after receiving written notice a default order may be entered against such licensee and the local liquor commissioner may impose such penalties as may be deemed appropriate e notwithstanding the provisions of subsections a d of this section if the local liquor commissioner or his designee has reason to believe that any continued operation of a particular licensed premises will immediately threaten the welfare of the community the commissioner may without notice or hearing order the licensed premises closed for not more than seven days giving the licensee an opportunity to be heard during that period except that if such licensee shall also be engaged in the conduct of another business or businesses on the licensed premises such order shall not be applicable to such other business f within five days after any hearing conducted pursuant to subsection d of this section the local liquor commissioner shall determine whether the license should be revoked or suspended locked pen or structure upon the premises of the owner of the dog the pen or structure must have secure sides and a secure top attached to the sides if the pen or structure has no bottom secured to the sides the sides must be embedded into the ground no less than one foot deep all such pens or structures must be adequately lighted and kept in a clean and sanitary condition vicious dog means any dog shall not suffer or permit the dog to go unconfined c leash and muzzle the owner of a vicious dog shall not suffer or permit the dog to go beyond the premises of the owner unless the dog is securely muzzled and restrained by a chain or leash and under the physical restraint of a person the muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration but shall prevent it from biting any human or animal d signs the owner of a vicious dog shall display in a prominent place on his premises a clearly visible warning sign indicating that there is a vicious dog on the premises a similar sign is required to be posted on the pen or kennel of the animal e killing vicious dogs it shall be lawful for the chief of police or other police officers to kill any vicious dog at large within the village which cannot safely be taken up and impounded f insurance owners of vicious dogs must provide proof to the village clerk of liability insurance in the amount of at least $10000000 insuring the owner for any personal injuries inflicted by his vicious dog g penalties whoever violates any provision of this section may be punished by a fine of not less than $5000 and not more than $50000  biting dogs  quarantine  rabies examination whenever any dog bites a person the owner of the dog shall immediately notify the chief of police the chief of police or his designee shall order the dog held on the owners premises or shall have it impounded for a period of ten days the dog shall be examined immediately after it has bitten anyone and again at the end of the tenday period if at the end of ten days a licensed veterinarian is convinced that the dog is then free from rabies the dog shall be released from quarantine or from the pound elimination idde article i  authority and purpose statutory authority a this chapter shall be known and may be cited as the westmont illicit discharge detection and elimination b the village of westmont board of trustees the board promulgate this chapter pursuant to their authority to adopt ordinances regulating the quality of all stormwater runoff channels streams and basins in the village of westmont in accordance with the adopted dupage county stormwater management plan the plan the plan represents the countys policy for management of stormwater quantity and quality the statutory authority for this chapter is contained in 65 ilcs 511 110 ilcs 511124 11152 and any other applicable authority as amended from time to time  762009 purposes of this chapter a the purpose of this chapter is to ensure the health safety and general welfare of the citizens of the village of westmont and dupage county and protect and enhance water quality in a manner pursuant to and consistent with the federal water pollution control act 33 usc  1251 et seq regulation of nonstormwater discharges to the storm drainage system this chapter establishes methods for controlling the introduction of discharges other than those occurring as a direct result of precipitation and or snow melt into the municipal separate storm sewer system ms4 and the storm drainage system in order to comply with requirements of the national pollutant discharge elimination system npdes phase ii permit process other purposes of this chapter include 1 to regulate the contribution of pollutants to the ms4 and the storm drainage system by non stormwater discharges  and 2 to prohibit illicit connections and discharges to the ms4 and the storm drainage system b the purposes of this chapter are consistent with the plan and advance the following objectives of the plan 1 protect and enhance the quality quantity and availability of surface and groundwater resources 2 preserve and enhance existing aquatic and riparian environments and encourage restoration of degraded areas 3 promote equitable acceptable and legal measures for stormwater management c the purposes of this chapter shall be implemented by its provisions  762009 secs 1631610  reserved article ii  definitions interpretation of terms and words for the purposes of this chapter the terms and words used herein shall be interpreted as follows 1
