in a manner different than that existing on the date of the passage of this comprehensive amendment and no structure hereafter erected or altered shall be occupied or used in whole or in part for any purpose whatsoever until a certificate of occupancy shall have been issued by the community development director stating that the structure or land improvement complies with all its plans and all the building and health laws and with the provisions of this comprehensive amendment no change of use shall be made in any structure or land improvement or part thereof now or hereafter erected or altered without an occupancy permit having been issued by the community development director and no permit shall be issued to make such change unless it is in conformity with the provisions of this comprehensive amendment and amendments thereto nothing in this section shall prevent the continuance of the present occupancy or use of any existing structure or land improvement except as may be necessary for the safety of life and property b no certificate of occupancy permit for a change of use in an existing structure or land improvement shall be issued until the premises have been inspected and certified by the economic development director to be in compliance with applicable requirements for the zoning district in which it is located c application for a certificate of occupancy shall be made and shall be issued within ten days after the erection or alteration of the structure has been completed a record of all certificates of occupancy shall be kept on file in the office of the community development director and copies shall be furnished on request to any person having proprietary or tenancy interest in the land or structure affected d pending the issuance of a regular certificate of occupancy a temporary permit may be issued to be valid for a period of no more than 60 days during months of the year permitting exterior construction and not more than 180 days during other times of the year application for a temporary permit shall be accompanied with a statement covering the items of work to be completed and the reasons the temporary permit is requested  642007   3232019 zoning escrow deposits any zoning applicant who submits a zoning application that requires the review of the planning and zoning commission shall in addition to meeting all other zoning application requirements fund an escrow account with the village to secure and cover reimbursement to the village for the reasonable fees of third party consultants to the village who provide professional consulting services on any matter pertaining to the applicants zoning application the zoning applicant shall complete a development escrow agreement on such form as proscribed by the community development director the community development director shall reasonably determine the amount of the escrow deposit required based on the complexity of the proposed development and the nature and extent of consulting services anticipated if the escrow deposit is depleted and additional consultant reviews are required the zoning applicant shall replenish the escrow account in such amount as reasonably determined by the community development director before further consultant reviews are performed the community development director shall promptly refund to the zoning applicant any deposit remaining in an escrow account after the completion of all consultant reviews  3232019 variations a authority the planning and zoning commission shall recommend all applications for variations of the provisions of this comprehensive amendment after a public hearing conducted by the planning and zoning commission the planning and zoning commission shall recommend a variation only after they have made findings of fact specifying the reason or reasons which justify the variation such findings shall be based upon the standards prescribed in subsection 1307d of this article b initiation an application for a variation may be made by any person firm or corporation having a freehold interest a possessory interest entitled to exclusive possession a contractual interest which may become a freehold interest an option to purchase or any exclusive possessory interest applicable to the land or land and improvements described in the application for a variation c application for variation and notice of hearing an application for a variation shall be filed with the community development department on forms prescribed by the village along with all required fees and required supporting documentation a copy of such application shall thereafter be forwarded by the community development department to the planning and zoning commission with a request to hold a public hearing and submit to the board of trustees a report of its findings and recommendations such public hearing shall be held upon public notice as required by the illinois compiled statutes variations granted shall be exercised within a period of 12 months after the date of the variation or shall otherwise become invalid any new construction or structural alterations performed in furtherance of the variance shall be diligently pursued to completion or the board of trustees may revoke the variance d standards for variations 1 the planning and zoning commission shall not recommend a variation to the regulations of this comprehensive amendment as authorized herein unless it shall have made findings of fact based upon the evidence presented to it in each specific case that a the property in question cannot yield a reasonable return if permitted to be used only under the conditions allowed by the regulations in the district in which it is located  b the plight of the owner is due to unique circumstances  and c the variation if granted will not alter the essential character of the locality 2 for the purpose of implementing the above rules the planning and zoning commission shall also in making its recommendations whether there are practical difficulties or particular hardships take into consideration the extent to which the following facts favorable to the applicant have been established by the evidence a the particular physical surroundings shape or topographical features of the specific property involved would result in a particular hardship upon the owner as distinguished from a mere inconvenience if the strict letter of the regulations were carried out b the conditions upon which the petition for variation is based would not be applicable generally to other property within the same zoning classification c the purpose of the variation is not based exclusively upon a desire to make more money out of the property d the alleged difficulty or hardship has not been created by the owner of the property e the granting of the variation will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property or improvements in the neighborhood in which the property is located f the proposed variation will not impair an adequate supply of light and air to adjacent property or substantially increase the congestion in the public streets or increase the danger of fire or endanger the public safety or substantially diminish or impair the property values within the neighborhood 3 the planning and zoning commission may recommend such conditions and restrictions upon the premises benefited by a variation as may be necessary to comply with the standards set forth in this subsection to reduce or minimize the injurious effect of such variation upon other property in the neighborhood and better to carry out the general intent of this comprehensive amendment e decisions the board of trustees upon report of the planning and zoning commission without further public hearing may grant or deny any proposed variation in accordance with illinois statutes and the westmont village or may refer it back to the planning and zoning commission for further consideration the board of trustees may by ordinance impose special conditions upon variance approval designed to protect the public health safety and welfare and designed to ensure compliance with the variance standards listed herein a violation of any such variance conditions shall constitute a violation of this zoning ordinance and shall constitute grounds for revocation of the variance  6191995   1262010   3232019 appeals an appeal to the planning and zoning commission may be made by any person firm or corporation or by any office department board or bureau aggrieved by a decision of the community development director under this comprehensive amendment in accordance with illinois statutes and the following a an application for an appeal shall be filed with the village clerk within 20 days of the date of the action from which the appeal is being filed and thereafter the village clerk shall forward such application to the planning and zoning commission for processing b an appeal stays all the proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the community development director from whom the appeal is taken certifies to the planning and zoning commission after the notice of appeal has been filed with him that by reason of facts stated in the certificate a stay would in his opinion cause imminent peril to life or property in which case proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order which may be granted by the planning and zoning commission or by a circuit court on application on notice to the economic development director from whom the appeal is taken and on due cause shown c the planning and zoning commission shall fix a reasonable time not to exceed 90 days for the hearing of the appeal and give due notice thereof to the parties and decide the same within a reasonable time the planning and zoning commission may reverse or affirm wholly or partly or may modify the order requirement decision or determinations as in its opinion ought to be made on the premises and to that end shall have all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal was taken  6191995   642007   3232019 special uses a purpose the formulation and enactment of a comprehensive zoning ordinance is based on the division of the entire village into districts in each of which are permitted specified uses that are mutually compatible in addition to such permitted compatible uses however it is recognized that there are other uses which it may be necessary or desirable to allow in a given district but which may have a unique special or unusual impact on the use and enjoyment of neighboring property and upon public facilities and therefore need to be carefully regulated with respect to location or operation for the protection of the community such uses are classified in this comprehensive amendment as special uses and fall into two categories 1 uses either municipally operated or operated by publicly regulated utilities or uses traditionally affected by public interest 2 uses entirely private in character which on account of their peculiar locational need the nature of the service they offer to the public and their possible damaging influence on the neighborhood may have to be established in a district or districts in which they cannot reasonably be allowed as an unrestricted permitted use under the regulations of this comprehensive amendment b initiation special uses may be proposed by any person firm or corporation having a freehold interest a possessory interest entitled to exclusive possession a contractual interest which may become a freehold interest an option to purchase or any exclusive possessory interest which is specifically enforceable on the land which is described in the application for a special use c processing 1 an application for a special use shall be filed with the community development department on forms prescribed by the village along with all required fees and required supporting documentation if not otherwise required by this zoning ordinance the community development department may require an applicant to submit a site plan for approval in conjunction with the special use request 2 a copy of such application shall thereafter be forwarded by the community development department to the planning and zoning commission with a request to hold a public hearing and submit to the board of trustees a report of its findings and recommendations such public hearing shall be held upon public notice as required by the illinois compiled statutes 3 after denial of a special use request by the village board the same applicant may not apply for the same or substantially similar special use for the property in question until at least one year have has elapsed since the date of the denial d standards a proposed special use shall substantially meet the following standards in order to obtain the recommendation of the planning and zoning commission and approval of the board of trustees 1 that the establishment maintenance or operation of the special use will not be detrimental to or endanger the public health safety morals comfort or general welfare 2 that the special use will not be injurious to the use and enjoyment of other property in the immediate vicinity for the purposes already permitted nor substantially diminish or impair property values within the neighborhood 3 that the establishment of the special use will not impede the normal and orderly development and improvement of surrounding property for uses permitted in the district 4 that adequate utilities access ways drainage andor other necessary facilities have been or are being provided 5 that adequate measures have been or will be taken to provide ingress and egress so designed as to minimize traffic congestion in the public streets 6 that the special use shall in all other respects conform to the applicable regulations of the district in which it is located except as such regulations may in each instance be modified by the village board pursuant to the recommendation of the plan commission e decisions the board of trustees upon report of the planning and zoning commission and without further public hearing may grant or deny any proposed special use in accordance with applicable illinois statutes or may refer it back to the planning and zoning commission for further consideration the board of trustees may by ordinance impose special conditions upon special use approval designed to protect the public health safety and welfare and designed to ensure compliance with the special use standards listed herein a violation of any such special use conditions shall constitute a violation of this zoning ordinance and shall constitute grounds for revocation of the special use f limitations on special uses 1 a special use shall apply only to the property for which it was originally granted 2 a special use shall run with the land except as limited herein a special use shall automatically terminate upon the cessation of the special use for a consecutive period of at least 365 days for purposes of this section cessation of the special use shall mean a failure to substantially operate the special use activity upon the property whether by affirmative choice bankruptcy liquidation foreclosure eviction or other reason a cessation of the special use shall not occur when the special use activity is temporarily halted due to the making of repairs or upgrades to the property where a building permit is obtained where the nature of the repairs or upgrades makes the continued operation of the special use impractical and where the repairs or upgrades are diligently pursued to completion 3 upon the termination of a special use for any reason new special use approval is required in order for that use to continue upon the property 4 a special use shall become null and void i 180 days after the date of village board approval if the special use is not commenced on the property unless the delay is due to construction or alteration of any structures in connection with the special use as addressed herein or ii 24 months after the date of village board approval if any construction or alteration of any structures in connection with the special use is not substantially completed and the special use in not commenced within that time period upon written request and good cause shown the board of trustees may by ordinance in its sole discretion grant extensions of the time limitations set forth in this section  6191995   1262010   3232019   8292019 reserved amendments a authority the regulations imposed and the districts created under the authority of this comprehensive amendment may be amended from title purpose and intent title this ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the westmont land development  purpose and jurisdiction because each new subdivision accepted by the village becomes a permanent unit in the basic physical structures of the future community to which the future community will of necessity be forced to adhere all subdivisions hereafter planned within the incorporated limits of the village and within the unincorporated area lying 1 miles beyond shall in all respects be in full compliance with the regulations hereinafter contained in this ordinance these regulations are designed to provide for the orderly and harmonious development of the village for the coordination of streets within new subdivisions with other existing or planned streets and to secure a uniform system of utilities and services and otherwise to promote realization of the comprehensive plan    6191995   512000 article ii  procedures general procedures before subdividing any tract or parcel of land in the village and the unincorporated areas within 1 miles beyond the village limits an owner or subdivider shall submit a preliminary plan and a final plat to be acted upon by the village authorities in accordance with the following requirements prior to the preparation of a preliminary plan it is recommended that 1 the owner or subdivider consult with the planning and zoning commission and other village officials to secure information relative to requirements of the comprehensive plan official map zoning ordinance and any other applicable village ordinance  and 2 subsequently submit to the planning and zoning commission a sketch plan of the proposed subdivision prepared on a topographic map of the area showing the local street system arrangement of lots and location of public use areas  6191995 preliminary plan a the owner or subdivider shall file an application for approval of the preliminary plan with the village clerk ten copies of the preliminary plan and the required filing fee shall accompany the application b the village clerk shall refer four copies of the preliminary plan to the planning and zoning commission at least ten days in advance of the next meeting of the planning and zoning commission c the planning and zoning commission shall notify the owner or subdivider as to the time and place of the planning and zoning commission meeting at which he will be afforded an opportunity of being heard d the planning and zoning commission shall approve or disapprove the application for preliminary plan approval within 90 days from the date of filing the application or the filing by the applicant of the last item of required supporting documents whichever date is later unless such time is extended by mutual consent if such plat is disapproved then within said 90 days the planning and zoning commission shall furnish to the applicant in writing a statement setting forth the reason for disapproval and specifying with particularity the aspects in which the proposed plat fails to conform to the zoning ordinance including the official map e if the preliminary plan has been approved by the planning and zoning commission it shall be referred to the board of trustees the board of trustees shall accept or reject said plan within a reasonable period of time after its next regular stated meeting following the action of the planning and zoning commission f upon approval of the preliminary plan by the village board the plan shall be marked approved and signed by the village clerk g four prints of such approved preliminary plan shall be distributed by the village clerk as follows 1 one print shall be sent to the planning and zoning commission  2 one print shall be sent to the public works director  3 one print shall be retained by the village clerk for filing  and 4 one print shall be returned to the subdivider h approval of the preliminary plan by the planning and zoning commission and board of trustees shall be conditioned upon stipulations as set forth in this ordinance  6191995   642007 plans and specifications for land improvements after the approval of the preliminary plan and prior to filing an application for approval of a final plat the subdivider shall submit to the public works director and other public officials having jurisdiction construction plans and specifications prepared by an illinois registered professional engineer for required land improvements such construction plans and specifications shall be approved by the public works director and other public officials having jurisdiction and such approval shall be certified on the final plat  642007 final plat a within one year after approval of the preliminary plan by the board of trustees the subdivider shall file with the village clerk an application for approval of the final plat covering all or a part of the approved preliminary plan such application shall include the original transparency drawings five contact prints of the final plat and four copies of all supporting maps drawings and all other required documents the final plat shall retain the design characteristics of the approved preliminary plan except that the board of trustees may require such changes or revisions as are deemed necessary in the interest and needs of the community otherwise if a preliminary plan is approved by the planning and zoning commission and the board of trustees the board of trustees cannot change the requirements for the particular subdivision if the final plat is presented within one year from date of acceptance of the preliminary plan accordingly the board of trustees may by resolution refer the application for approval of the final plat to the planning and zoning commission for recommendation and report relative to design characteristics of the final plat b in case application for approval of a final plat is made for only a part of the approved preliminary plan the board of trustees may extend the time for filing application for approval of final plats covering the remaining area included in the approved preliminary plan until a later date or dates beyond the foregoing oneyear period c within a reasonable time from the date of filing the last required document or other paper or within 60 days from the date the application for approval of the final plat was filed with the village clerk whichever date is later the board of trustees shall by resolution approve or disapprove such final plat upon the adoption of the resolution approving a final plat the village clerk shall certify such approval and affix the corporate seal of the village on the final plat d upon approval by the board of trustees and recording of the final plat with the dupage county recorder of deeds the original transparency shall be submitted to the public works director along with three copies of the recorded plat one of which shall be retained by the public works director one by the the owner or subdivider in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the public works director and board of trustees and all inspection fees required by this ordinance and one set of plans and specifications showing such improvements as installed shall be filed with the village clerk within two years following the approval of the final plat by the board of trustees no required land improvements shall be installed prior to the recording of the final plat b a cash security deposit commercial bank letter of credit or completion bond shall be submitted by such owner or subdivider to the public works director prior to recording of the final plat in the case of completion bonds the village manager shall not accept a completion bond in excess of $500000 such cash security deposit commercial bank letter of credit or completion bond shall be in a sum sufficient to cover 110 percent of the cost of the land improvements required by this ordinance plus the cost of inspection fees including engineering fees by the village in regard to the subdivision such cost for the completion of the required land improvements plus inspection fees and engineering fees shall be in accordance with the cost estimates approved by the public works director all letters of credit must be obtained commercial bank licensed to do business in the state the owner or subdivider shall submit any letter of credit to the village finance department and the village public works department for preapproval prior to submission of the letter of credit to the commercial bank all letters of credit must contain an atsight clause regarding payment all letters of credit must contain an expiration date no earlier than 45 days after the expected completion date renewals of letters of credit shall be as provided in subsection c of this section a $5000 administration fee shall accompany all letters of credit submitted to the village finance department for preapproval all cash security deposits shall be used insofar as it is sufficient to defray the cost of making such improvements including inspection fees and engineering fees any unused balance will be returned to the depositor in accordance with state law the cash security deposit commercial bank letter of credit or completion bond shall be conditioned upon the installation of such improvements and payment of inspection fees including engineering fees within two years following the approval of the final plat and satisfactory maintenance of those public improvements prior to village acceptance there shall be no reduction of that portion of the letter of credit bond or deposit applying to a particular improvement unless or until that improvement is complete and accepted or approved by the public works director and then on reduction shall be in the amount of 90 percent of the cost of such improvement as determined by the public works director no security shall be returned until asbuilt drawings as required in article v section 507 of this ordinance have been filed with the public works director c upon the approval of the public works director a letter of credit may be renewed for additional periods of time to enable the owner or subdivider to complete the required land improvements not less than 30 days and not more than 60 days prior to the expiration of the letter of credit the public works director shall notify the owner or subdivider in writing of the pending expiration and not less than ten days prior to such expiration date the owner or subdivider shall be required to provide the public works director with evidence that such letter of credit has been renewed for the approved additional period of time if the owner or subdivider fails to renew such letter of credit within the time allowed the public works director shall either i allow renewal of the letter of credit prior to its expiration date upon payment of $80000 to the village by the owner or subdivider to compensate the village for costs associated with such late renewal  or ii proceed to make a draw on the letter of credit prior to its expiration no owner or subdivider shall be permitted to renew its letter of credit at any time which is less than ten days prior to its expiration date without paying the required fee as set forth herein d the village clerk shall not certify the approval of the board of trustees on the final plat until the required bond or deposit or cash or other guarantee has been filed as required by this section note if the subdivision is located in the unincorporated area within 1 miles beyond the village limits and the owner or subdivider has agreed with dupage county to complete required improvements for the subdivision then the owner or subdivider shall not be required to agree to such completion with the village as set forth in paragraph a above  provided however that if the villages standards for such improvements are of higher quality than the standards of dupage county then the owner or subdivider shall be required to agree to install such improvements in accordance with the villages standards    411996   9201999   642007   642007 acceptance and guarantee of streets a is authorized to enter into snow control agreements with developers to allow village snow plowing of dedicated but unaccepted streets until such time that said streets are formally accepted by the village b guarantee and repair or replacement the developer shall repair or replace any public improvement which has or will become defective due to work or material provided and shall so repair or replace within 30 days of receipt of a written notice from the public works director that such defect or defects exist the developer shall provide prior to acceptance security to the village for repair or replacement of defective public improvements by submission of a cash security deposit commercial bank letter of credit or a maintenance bond in the amount of 15 percent of the cost of construction of the public improvements and in no event in an amount less than $100000 the cash security deposit commercial bank letter of credit or a maintenance bond shall be in such form as approved by the village attorney and conditioned upon repair or replacement of defective public improvements within one year after acceptance if the developer fails to properly repair or replace defects after notice as provided above the security shall be used by the village for said repair or replacement any unused portion of the security shall be returned to the developer after one year from acceptance of the public improvements and only after all repairs and replacements as required are completed    12182006   642007 article iii  content of preliminary and final plats preliminary also be required  6191995   642007 footnotes  2  for plats outside corporate limits article iv  subdivision design standards streets a street plan the arrangement character extent width grade and location of all streets shall conform to the comprehensive plan and shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets  to reasonable circulation of traffic within the subdivision and adjoining lands  to topographical conditions  to runoff of stormwater  to public convenience and safety  and in their appropriate relations to the proposed uses of the area to be served b streets and other ways 1 rightofway widths shall conform to the following minimum dimensions type residential subdivision manufacturing or business subdivision a arterials as shown on official map and in no instance less than 80 feet as shown on official map and in no instance less than 80 feet b collector streets 70 feet 80 feet c minor streets 60 feet 70 feet d culdesac streets 60 feet 70 feet e frontage road 45 feet 45 feet f half streets onehalf the rightofway of the proposed street or as required by the planning and zoning commission not permitted g utility easements 10 feet 10 feet h alleys if permitted 20 feet 30 feet i pedestrian ways 15 feet 15 feet 2 minor streets shall be so aligned that their use by will be discouraged 3 streets should intersect at right angles or form ts and ys acute angle intersections should be avoided jogs in street intersections should be at least 150 feet apart 4 a culdesac street in singlefamily residential districts shall be not more than 600 feet in length measured along its centerline from the centerline of the street of origin to the end of its rightofway or it may be longer than 600 feet provided that not more than 26 lots have exclusive access from it on both sides of the street in multiplefamily residential districts such streets shall not exceed 300 feet in length each culdesac shall have a terminus of circular shape with a minimum diameter of 120 feet except a culdesac street that has not more than five lots fronting on its rightofway or a temporary culdesac street may have a terminus of the t type or other variation of shape as approved by the planning and zoning commission 5 where there is a deflection in horizontal centerlines in excess of ten degrees a curve shall be inserted having a centerline radius of not less than 125 feet for minor streets and not less than 300 feet for collector streets a tangent of at least 100 feet in length shall be provided between all horizontal curves 6 half streets shall be prohibited except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of these regulations and where the board of trustees finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided wherever an existing or dedicated half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided the other half of the street shall be platted within such tract a half street where included shall be graded at one level and the regrading or new construction of any half street shall conform to the grade and pavement of the adjacent half street where a half street is provided the developer shall be required to deposit sufficient funds in escrow to cover the cost of its resurfacing when the balance of the street is constructed 7 provisions shall be made for vehicular and pedestrian access to residential property abutting a thoroughfare either by a frontage roads or b double frontage lots backing to the thoroughfare where the double frontage backup treatment is used a noaccess strip shall be provided these standards are established for the purpose of providing protection to residential properties and to separate local traffic 8 gradients of street gutters shall be at least fourtenths of one percent and of centerlines shall not exceed five percent for collector streets and six percent for minor streets 9 where streets are dedicated whether used or not but not improved to the standards of this ordinance and are wholly within the proposed subdivision land they shall be improved to the standards of this ordinance  6191995 easements a easements shall be provided for underground utility services including stormwater drainage water main and sanitary sewer service where necessary they shall be a minimum of ten feet wide or larger if determined by the public works director and shall be established at the rear of each lot and along such other lot lines as to provide continuity of alignment from block to block if located between two adjoining lots the easement shall be centered on the property line b where a subdivision is traversed by a natural watercourse drainageway channel or stream there shall be provided a drainage easement approved by the public works director conforming substantially with the lines of such watercourse andor as approved by the public works director  642007 blocks a in residential subdivisions the maximum length of blocks containing any lots less than 100 feet in width shall be 1500 lineal feet and the maximum length of blocks containing lots 100 feet and over in width shall be 2000 lineal feet no blocks shall be less than 900 lineal feet in length unless approved by the planning and zoning commission pedestrian ways leading to schools parks or other common destinations may be required by the planning and zoning commission for blocks over 900 feet in length pedestrian ways not less than 15 feet in width shall be provided where deemed necessary by the planning and zoning commission b in industrial and business districts maximum length of blocks shall be as approved by the planning and zoning commission c the shape of blocks shall be determined by topographical features the basic street system and traffic pattern lot depths and areas designated for public and other nonresidential land uses d where a subdivision borders upon or at a distance removed suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land ie park purposes deep residential lots fronting on it with a noaccess strip along the rear property lines and offstreet area of lots shall conform with lot width and area requirements set forth in the zoning ordinance of the village or that of dupage county in the unincorporated areas beyond the village limits corner lots shall be increased in width by 20 percent over the width of typical interior lots except that corner lots need not exceed 90 feet in width if the 90 feet in width is greater than the width of the typical lot 3 double frontage lots shall be permitted only where lots back up on an arterial street provided that no vehicular access between the lots and the arterial street is permitted  or where the topography of the land might render subdividing otherwise unreasonable 4 in the subdividing of any land due regard shall be shown for all natural features such as tree growth watercourses or similar conditions b residential subdivision 1 all lots for singlefamily detached residential use shall abut upon a street or easement flag lots are prohibited 2 double frontage lots shall be permitted only where lots back up on an arterial street provided that no vehicular access between the lots and the arterial street is permitted  or where the topography of the land might render subdividing otherwise unreasonable provided that an additional depth of ten feet shall be required as a no access strip to provide protective screen planting c industrial subdivision 1 depth of lots shall be not less than 200 feet 2 all lots for industrial subdivision shall abut upon a street flag lots are prohibited 3 double frontage lots shall be permitted only where lot depth is 300 feet or more  where lots back up on an arterial street provided that no vehicular access between the lots and the arterial street is permitted  or where the topography of the land might render subdividing otherwise unreasonable  6182007 public use areas the planning and zoning commission may recommend and the village board may require each applicant to dedicate land for park and recreational purposes and land for school sites to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the parcel to make a cash contribution in lieu of actual land dedication or to provide a combination of both at the option of the village such dedication is necessary to ensure proper provision of park and school sites for persons who are expected to reside within the subdivision or development which sites would otherwise have to be acquired at the expense of the general public but whose utility would generally be limited to residents of the parcel a criteria for requiring park and recreation land dedication 1 applicant may be required to dedicate for park and recreation purposes an amount of land determined on the basis of 55 acres per 1000 persons calculated as provided in paragraph e table of estimated ultimate population 2 the location of the site to be dedicated shall be determined by the village board upon recommendation of the planning and zoning commission and the westmont park district taking into account the suitability of the site for park purposes or development its relationship to population concentrations and its proximity to other park or recreational lands 3 no storage of any materials including spoil materials or topsoil will be allowed on any land designated as park district land for use as recreational use 4 credit for private open space and recreation areas private open space or recreation areas may be utilized in lieu of the dedication required by this subsection a provided that detailed improvement plans shall be approved by the planning and zoning commission and village board and that satisfactory guarantees of the permanency of the use and its maintenance enforceable by the village shall be entered into by the applicant b criteria for school site dedication applicants may be required to dedicate for school purposes an amount of land determined by 1 obtaining the ratio of estimated children to be generated by the proposed table in this paragraph b 2 multiplying that ratio by the minimum number of acres for a school site within each school classification determined from the table in this paragraph b calculation to be extended to three decimals 3 no storage of any materials including spoil materials or topsoil will be allowed on any land designated as future or proposed school sites base school population and site size school classification by grades maximum number of students for each such school classification minimum number of acres of land for each school site of such classification elementary schools grades kindergarten k5 600 11 junior high schools grades 6 68 900 19 high schools grades 9 912 2300 48 c criteria for requiring a contribution in lieu of park and school sites where the resulting site in a proposed subdivision or development is too small to be usable for the purpose intended or where it is inappropriate for park and recreational purposes or a school site the village may require the applicant to contribute cash in lieu of the land dedication the cash contributions in lieu of park and recreation land dedication shall be held in trust by the village or other public body designated by the village solely for the acquisition of park and recreation land as hereinbefore classified which will serve the immediate or future needs of the residents of that subdivision or development or for the improvement of other existing park and recreation land which already serves such needs the cash contributions in lieu of school sites shall be held in trust by the village or other public body designated by the village solely for use in the acquisition of land for a school site to serve the immediate or future needs of children from that subdivision or development or for the improvement to any existing school site which already serves such needs but not for the construction of any school buildings or additions thereto if any portion of a cash contribution in lieu of park and recreation land dedication or cash contribution in lieu of school site is not expended for the purposes set forth herein within seven years from the date of receipt it shall be refunded to the applicant who made such contribution 1 fair market value the cash contribution in lieu of land shall be based on the fair market value of the acres of land as improved that otherwise would have been dedicated as park and recreation or school sites it has been determined that the present fair market value of such improved land in and surrounding the village is $12500000 per acre and such figure shall be used in making any calculation herein unless the applicant files written object thereto in the event of any such objection the applicant shall submit an appraisal showing the fair market value per acre of such improved land or other evidence thereof and final determination of said fair market value per acre of such improved land shall be made by the village board based upon such information from other sources which may be submitted to the village board by the park district school district or others d criteria for requiring dedication and a fee there will be situations when a combination of land dedication and a contribution in lieu of land is necessary these occasions will arise when 1 the subdivision or development does not have sufficient or adequate land to meet the dedication requirements hereunder that portion of the land within the subdivision or development which is adequate or sufficient for the park or school location shall be dedicated as a site as aforesaid and a cash contribution in lieu thereof shall be required for any additional land that would have been required to be dedicated 2 a major part of the local park or recreation site or school site has already been acquired and only a small portion of land is needed from the subdivision or development to complete the site the portions needed to complete the park or school site shall be dedicated and a cash contribution shall be required in lieu of the balance of the required dedication e density formula the following table of population density is generally indicative of current and short range projected trends in family size for new construction and shall be used in calculating the amount of required dedication of acres of land or the cash contributions in lieu thereof unless a written objection is filed thereto by the applicant in the event an applicant files a written objection to the table of estimated ultimate population listed herein he shall submit his own demographic study showing the estimated additional population and in that event final determination of the density formula to be used in such calculations shall be made by the village board based upon such demographic information submitted by the applicant and from other sources which may be submitted to the village board by the park district school district or others f improved sites the slope topography and geology of the site to be dedicated as well as its surroundings must be suitable for its intended purposes grading on sites dedicated for park and recreational uses shall not differ greatly from surrounding land before dedication all sites shall be improved as required under this ordinance or acceptable provisions shall be made for such improvement before dedication    6191995   1221996 _____ districts six feet 4 trees shall be planted along all streets where trees do not exist trees shall have a trunk diameter measured 12 inches above the ground of not less than three inches and shall be spaced not more than 50 feet apart this requirement will be satisfied if an equivalent number of trees of the same size or larger size are planted in a naturalistic manner in the front yards of the adjoining lots the plantings shall be restricted to thornless honey locusts sugar maples hackberries pin oaks sycamore ginkgoes andor any other trees approved by the planning and zoning commission chinese elm box elder willow poplar silver maple cottonwood american elm and similar fastgrowing brittlewood species are prohibited trees shall be maintained and dead trees replaced by the subdivider for a period of two years after initial planting 5 street signs shall be provided by the subdivider in accordance with village standards and specifications and shall be located so as to identify every street within the subdivision 6 provisions shall be made for the electric lighting of streets within the proposed subdivision with the plans for such installation subject to village approval 7 concrete barriertype curbs shall be provided for all parking lots accommodating five or more parking spaces for the purpose of protecting landscaping improving site maintenance preventing vehicle encroachment and controlling drainage d waiver and cash in lieu of certain public improvements 1 in certain instances where it is impractical or undesirable that certain of the abovestated public improvements be installed at the time of development the public works director may allow a waiver of certain public improvements if a waiver is granted then a cash contribution shall be made to the village for such public improvements which are not installed 2 the criteria for waiving certain public improvements and requiring a cash contribution are as follows streets a where road widening will be 250 feet or less in length exclusive of any transitional tapers as measured parallel to the centerline on the rightofway b where road widening will require transitional pavement extending outside of the corporate boundaries of the village c where the public works department determines that road widening may conflict with other existing or planned public improvements street lighting d where only one street light is required by design standard e where the public works department determines that adequate street illumination exists in the immediate area f where the public works department determines that the required street light location andor type may conflict with other existing or planned public improvements 3 where a cash contribution is allowed in lieu of certain public improvements the amount of such contribution shall be approximately equal to the cost of constructioninstallation of the waived public improvements the public works director shall publish a contribution schedule based on the approximate cost of constructioninstallation of each public improvement the cash contribution shall be paid upon or before completion of public improvements for the 205b  642007 article vi  general provisions minimum standards for subdivisions all subdivisions shall meet the following requirements a the side lines of all lots shall be approximately perpendicular to the street line b the minimum depth of residential lots shall be 125 feet and the minimum width 60 feet unless otherwise provided by the zoning ordinance c all corner lots shall be so platted as to maintain the full required setback as required by the village zoning ordinance upon both streets d in subdivisions bordering on railroads streets parallel to the railroad shall be so laid out as to leave a 150foot strip of land alongside the railroad rightofway to provide for clear vision and for safe grades in case of grade separation this land shall be dedicated to park purposes wherever practicable but where necessary may be platted for industrial commercial or residential uses e reserved    5141973     4161984 editors note this appendix was originally designated  2432 of the 1972 or replatting until required utility facilities have been installed and made ready to service the structure or land improvement and until roadways providing access to the lot or lots containing such improvements have been constructed or are in the course of construction and are suitable for vehicular traffic variations a recommending variances  the planning and zoning commission may recommend variances from the literal application of the design standards specified in this section 1 where conformance with these standards is made impossible by topography or surrounding development  or 2 where an existing plat is to be replatted in a manner which more nearly complies with these requirements than the existing plat b conditions in recommending any variance the planning and zoning commission shall specify conditions necessary to assure that the proposed subdivision 1 will not be detrimental to the neighborhood and to the community as a whole  2 complies with the comprehensive plan of the village  3 complies with the intent of this ordinance  4 does not violate any other ordinances or regulations of the village c procedure such recommendations shall be communicated to the board of trustees or governing county authorities in writing substantiating the recommended variations the board of trustees or county authorities may approve variations from these requirements for subdivisions when in its opinion such variations will not adversely affect the comprehensive plan or the spirit of this ordinance the village shall notify the owner or subdivider and other interested parties as to the time and place of the planning and zoning commission meeting at which the variations are being considered and where the owner or subdivider and other interested parties will be afforded an opportunity of being heard such notice shall be published posted or delivered in such form as prescribed by the village attorney where the development has been processed as a planned development in accordance with the provisions of the westmont zoning ordinance variations to the development code may be incorporated within the planned development documents without the necessity for separate hearings or separate action by the planning and zoning commission or the board of trustees  6191995 enforcement no plat of any subdivision shall be entitled to be recorded in the recorders office or have any validity until it shall have been approved in a manner prescribed in this ordinance record of plats all of such plats of subdivision after the same have been submitted and approved as provided in this ordinance and recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds of dupage county shall be filed and kept by the village clerk among the records of the village separability if any section subsection sentence clause or phrase of this ordinance is for any reason held to be invalid such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this ordinance violation  penalty a any person firm or corporation which is charged with a duty under this ordinance and who fails neglects or refuses to abide by the same or to perform such duty or who knowingly violates any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not less than $2500 or more than $50000 each day that the violation of this ordinance continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense and shall be punishable as such b whoever shall sell or offer for sale lease or offer for lease while this ordinance is in effect any lot or lots or block or blocks within the incorporated limits of the village or any additions thereto or any resubdivision of any lot or block therein or within contiguous territory and not more than 1 miles beyond the incorporated boundary of the village before all of the requirements of this ordinance have been complied with shall be fined not less than $2500 or more than $25000 for each lot block or part thereof so disposed of offered for sale or leased article vii  rules and definitions rules the language set forth in the text of this ordinance shall be interpreted in accordance with the following rules of construction a the singular number includes the plural and the plural the singular b the present tense includes the past and future tenses and the future the present c the word shall is mandatory while the word may is permissive d the masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter e whenever a word or term defined hereinafter appears in the text of the ordinance its meaning shall be construed as set forth in the definition thereof  and any word appearing in parentheses directly after a word herein defined shall be construed in the same sense as that word f the following words and terms wherever they occur in this ordinance shall be construed as herein defined definitions alley is a rightofway which affords secondary means of access to properties abutting upon a street arterial is a street with a high degree of continuity and serving as an arterial trafficway between the various districts of westmont and its environs bedroom is any room in a dwelling which has all of the following characteristics i it is larger than 100 square feet in area  ii it has access to a full bathroom with a shower or bathtub on the same level of the dwelling  iii it has a closet  and iv it is not open to any other room block is a tract of land bounded by streets or by a combination of streets and public parks railroad rightsofway or other similar natural or manmade boundaries a block may be located in part beyond the corporate limits of the village board of trustees is the board of trustees of the village of westmont illinois building setback line is a line within a lot or other parcel of land which denotes the area between such line and the adjacent street rightofway line where a building and other obstructions are prohibited except those encroachments that are permitted by zoning ordinance regulations collector street is a street within a subdivision which has wider rightofway and roadway widths and which is a prime entrance or circulating street its primary function is to distribute and collect traffic to and from minor streets comprehensive plan refers to the composite of the functional and geographic elements of the official comprehensive plan of the village and its environs or any segment thereof in the form of plans maps charts reports implementing ordinances and the official map culdesac is a minor street with a single outlet and is permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround easement is a quantity of land set aside over or under which a liberty privilege or advantage in land without profit is dedicated or granted either to the public a particular person or a combination of both and is distinct from ownership of the land economic development director is the building inspector of the village of westmont or his duly authorized representative final plat is a map or plan of a subdivision and any accompanying material as described in article iii of this ordinance flag lot is a lot having the configuration of an extended flag and pole the pole represents access to the building site which is usually located to the rear of another lot fronting a dedicated street the width of the pole measures less than the required minimum lot width for the zoning district frontage road is a minor road which is parallel to and either adjacent to or within the rightofway of a thoroughfare half street is a street of less than the total required width among one or more boundary lines of a subdivision land improvement is any sanitary sewerage system storm sewer system water supply and distribution system roadway sidestrip sidewalk pedestrian way noaccess strip offstreet parking area lot grading or other improvement which the village may require under this ordinance lot is a portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land intended for transfer of ownership or for building development lot butt is a lot at the end of a block and located between two corner lots lot double frontage is a lot which has a pair of opposite lot lines along two substantially parallel streets minor street is a street of limited continuity its primary purpose is to serve abutting properties noaccess strip is a land area at least 12 feet wide along the rear lot lines of double frontage lots and abutting a thoroughfare within which no private vehicular driveway or walkway shall be permitted owner or subdivider shall include any person firm association partnership private corporation public or quasipublic corporation or a combination of any of them or other legal entity having sufficient proprietary interest in the land sought to be subdivided or divided to commence and maintain proceedings under the provisions of this ordinance pedestrian way is a rightofway across or within a block designated for pedestrian use planning and zoning commission is the village of westmont planning and zoning commission preliminary plan is a map depicting a tentative land plan as described in article iii of this ordinance public works director is a professional engineer registered in the state of illinois who has been duly appointed as the public works director of the village roadway is that portion of the street designated for vehicular use sidestrip is the unpaved strip of land within a street rightofway and is parallel to the roadway sidewalk is that portion of the street designated for pedestrian use street is a rightofway which affords primary means of access by pedestrians and vehicles to abutting properties whether designated as a street avenue highway road boulevard easement or however otherwise designated street width is the shortest distance between the rightofway lines of a given street subdivision is 1 a described tract of land which is to be or has been divided into two or more parcels of land  2 any division of land which creates a lot for transfer of ownership andor building development where a new street is involved  or 3 the dedication of streets ways or other areas for the use of the public all subdivisions shall comply with the provisions of the village land development code where applicable with the exception of recording of a final plat when such recording is specifically exempted under the plat act 765 ilcs 205001 et seq as may be amended from time to time subdivision design standards are the basic landplanning principles established as guides for the
